Evidence of sex differences in COVID-19 severity emerged in China, where hospital admissions and mortality were higher among males than females
6â€“ 8 . In South Korea, where community testing was widespread, females represented ~60% of those testing positive for SARS-CoV-2, suggesting that females acquire infection, despite having a lower case fatality rate (CFR)
9, 10 . In the United States, where testing was prioritized for people with symptomatic disease, the diagnosis rates were similar in males and females, but males had 1.5 times higher mortality
11 .
